narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Very good course, but did not provide much additional information than Epi I. I felt as if it were a repeat/refresher course and did not go more in depth into epidemiology, which is what I had been hoping for. Homeworks and exams were fair.
There was a lot of repetition with the Epi 1 course, however, the content of the course was clear and well organized

this was a very challenging class and i have yet to master any of the material. i felt like a lot of it was a review of the first semester but it was still very challenging. this is hard material to grasp.

It as a great course - good use of literature to directly demonstrate the points being made in class.The only issue I had was that it was very repetitive of Epi 1, and we learned only a few new things. In my opinion it would make more sense to teach it as a continuous two semester class, so we wouldn't have to spend most of the time on review.

The homeworks were very hard and graded very strictly. If the homeworks had been graded on completion and not on perfection, the class would have been less stressful. The exams seemed very fair and the in-class examples were great. I was frustrated by how much this overlapped with the content of EPI 1. Many of the subjects were the same, though taught slightly differently. I would have preferred new subject matter and less repetition.
the lectures were well prepared and thought out. excellent class overall.
Great class but difficult to pay attention.

Strengths- in depth look at some of the conceptual ideas in epi. Instructor is interesting and funny- good stories and depth of knowledge on material.Weakness- calculations were glossed over in class. although they were covered in the HW it could have been helpful to offer an occasional lab to walk through the problems. More practice probs would have better helped prepare students for the exam; Also seemed like a shame to go through so many papers and then not have the opportunity to discuss them as a class. Presentations on papers were interesting but didnt allow for as much independent thought.

A lot of the course material was exact repetition of material from the first semester. It would have been nice to try to vary it up a bit, either by going more in-depth or approaching from a different perspective.
Excellent.

This course was great. It was very straightforward and presented the issues in a clear and concise manner. The only change I would make is that readings need to be posted at least 72 hours in advance of lecture. Often we had only 12-24 hours to complete them which was often impractical.
It was really informative but I would have wished if they arranged optional sessions with the TAs where they solve the assignments to students so that we know what we did wrong.
good.
This course is very worthy to take. It refreshed and intensified my epi knowledge.

Epi II would be a decent course in epidemiology taken on it's own, but in conjunction with Epi I it is a waste of time. At least 90% of the material covered in Epi II is a repeat of what was covered in Epi I. It has value only for students who did not do well or did not understand the material in Epi I. Personally, however, I found that the material was covered more clearly in Epi I (with Dr. Niccolai). This course is a waste of time for students who worked hard in Epi I and a waste of time and money for YSPH in allocating class and professor time. At the very least, Epi II should not be a required course for any division.

strengths: interesting and entertaining professor, read/dissection of journal articles, study types, study quality, applying the epi principles we know, etc.weaknesses: a lot of repeat from the first semester!
Strengths- reaffirmed concepts learned in epi 1. at times felt like a rehash of information though

This course is more-or-less a review of Epi I. Although we went into more detail for certain topics (e.g., matching), most of the material was review of first semester's epi. While Professor Desai is an intelligent and engaging instructor (with a snarky sense of humor that I believe most students relished), the material was redundant.

I enjoyed Epi II. Prof. Desai was extremely amusing (in a very good, educational way) and I loved some of the articles he used in class. If it wasn't for data management this semester (which he also taught) I would say this would be my favorite class.

The course was EXCELLENT. I really recommend it to all biostat phD students. I feel like it really rounded out my education. I feel VERY secure in the major epi concepts which, I think, already help me as a biostat student. A+++, Mayur! :)

I think it's a very strong course overall-one of the strongest at EPH. I would have benefited from a little more information on errors made on the problem sets, but other than that, the class is very well-taught.

3 strengths:The instructor is engaging and fun, and does not make epidemiology a chore to study for at all.The readings are diverse and unpredictable, but always relevant.The homework assignments are easy to follow, good at reinforcing concepts learned in class and great revision guides for exams.weaknesses?It's too short :) I wish Dr Desai could have taught us more epi(maybe Epi 3?)

What I appreciated most about this course was the introduction to new topics in epidemiology, including life tables, survival analysis, in-depth discussion on matching, and meta-analysis. There is quite a bit of overlap with epi I; however, given the importance of this material, I feel that it's useful to hear the information again and in a slightly different way.

I really loved this course. I had taken an epidemiology course in my undergraduate major, so during the first semester, these concepts were not new to me, but the course first semester was still quite challenging. This semester, all of these concepts became very clear to me and were taught in a way that they were applicable to current projects and interests.

This class is extremely redundant with Epi I, and I am resentful of the fact that I had to take both. There were only a couple concepts that we didn't learn last semester in Linda Niccolai's class, and those could have easily been added to Epi I. It was almost as if Dr. Desai didn't look at Dr. Niccolai's syllabus--if he had, he would have seen that the two courses cover the EXACT same material. Please remove this class from the required SBS curriculum; it's completely unnecessary.
An excellent course with few flaws.
Great class!

This course helped me to develop a more critical approach when reading and promoted a more sophisticated understanding of methodology. There is a lot of overlap with epi I, however, which could sometimes be frustrating, although it certainly doesn't hurt to review some of the concepts.
This course is very comprehensive

The case studies were interesting, but not crucial to performance in the course, so I think that's why attendance may have dropped off. I attended almost all lectures, but found them not necessary. The material, while a review of Epi I, was difficult, but not unreasonably so.

The emphasis in class was not the emphasis on the exams. The midterm was all calculations and the final was calculations and important concepts/ideas. There was a big focus on the readings, but we were never tested on them.

Strengths: covers concepts from first semester more in-depthCons: assignments were not fairly spaced out over the course of the semester (5 homework assignments and 2 of the 5 were due in the same week at the very end of the semester)

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  On homework assignments, lot of point substraction for small mistakes (maximal penalty, despite good reasoning). Also lot of point extractions for similar repeated mistakes.

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Very good and funny professor; I liked the use of real-life examples of epidemiology studies to emphasize material. However, I wish lecture slides had been totally content-driven rather than including study examples. Also, a few of the slides were a little confusing which made studying more difficult.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  The professor explained things well, however, his attitude toward students and his professional colleagues was poor and at times rude
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  desai is a hard teacher and generally presents the information well. however, his homeworks and exams are very challenging.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  He was great!

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  He puts together good lectures. He expects a lot of his students and doesn't "dumb" anything down. This makes for a challenge but also makes the course more interesting.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  the professor was very knowledgeable on the subject. it's evident that he has sufficient experience and background in the field.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Great teacher with a no nonsense attitude.

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  As noted above, Professor Desai is interesting and knowledgeable. He offered perspective on epi concepts and presented in an interesting manner.Again, calculations were sometimes glossed over in class.

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Dr. Desai was an interesting lecturer, but the problem was that the course material was exactly the same as first semester, leading to a somewhat biased impression of his lectures as being the same old material.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Excellent.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Mayur is a great teacher.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Dr Desai was excellent instructor and had good control of the knowledge required for this class.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  teaches well.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Dr. Desai organized the lectures very well and delivered it in a clear way. I like his course.

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Dr. Desai is a personable lecturer and tries hard to assign interesting/amusing readings that hold the class's attention. New material, however, would have held my attention better.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  good, entertaining

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Desai is one of the reasons I came to Yale- sat in an Epi II lecture last year and loved it. Think he's a good teacher and an engaging lecturer, albeit a little sarcastic at times...not that I minded! Makes epi relatively clear and easy to understand- no easy feat!
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Dr. Desai is a very good instructor who can explain difficult concepts well.

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Professor Desai presented the material coherently and consistently attempted to put an interesting spin in the lecture with unique articles to read. No major negatives - although at times he could be rather intimidating.

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  He's great! Strengths--he's engaging/good lecture, goes through the material without insulting our intelligence (I mean that in the less vain way as possible--compared to other profs, whom I found unable to fully connect and earned complete respect from students). Weakness--there really wasn't any.

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Prof. Desai is absolutely amazing. Aside from being brilliant and having killer shoes (!), he is just a really nice guy. LOVED taking a class with him, LOVED talking to him in office hours, LOVED his lecture notes...just all-around loved him. He's organized, caring, andsmart. He knew my name (and, it's a HUGE class) on the second day. He was the first professor I've had at Yale to do that. He wrote really good exams, we had fantastic examples in class. The homework was helpful and worked as a nice review of all of the work we had done in class. It is a very applied class, but if you ask about the theory, Prof. Desai knows what he is talking about. By FAR the best professor I've had in the public health school. I really can't say enough good things about him and his class. I think that it should be a mandatory experience to study with Prof. Desai; he is the "gold standard." The *only* criticism I have of the class is that I didn't like the text book. That being said, Prof. Desai only assigns select chapters/readings so even that wasn't horrible. Honestly, I don't think he should change anything because it was a wonderful experience!

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Dr. Desai is a phenomenal teacher. I appreciated that he tried to make every class relevant to the greater field of academic epidemiology. His slides are very clear (albeit lacking in color), and it was a great way to understand the practical aspects of epi.

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  He's an excellent teacher. By far, my favorite instructor thus far. He makes learning fun by relating concepts to real-life epi problems. He's also approachable and friendly.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  The instructor was an excellent, charismatic lecturer. What I appreciated most about the instructor was his organization and no-nonsense, step-by-step explanations.

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Dr. Desai was an amazing instructor! I very much enjoyed attending lectures because he clearly explained the concepts and gave excellent examples, making class time worthwhile and fun. He has a great sense of humor and really brings even mundane topics to life. He was great at answering questions and being clear about his expectations for the class.

Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  His slides are extremely clear and instructive. His lecturing style is dry but precise. The high quality of the slides disincentivized me from attending lecture, for better or for worse.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Great presentations and very knowledgeable and approachable.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Great instructor!
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  The instructor was excellent and responsive to student needs.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  Dr. Desai is excellent
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  I liked him a lot and was really happy with the way he taught the course. Although some people were mad about how difficult the final was, I thought it was fair.
Instructor: Mayur Mahesh Desai  He could have been more patient with people. He was pretty negative about research methods and most things that are published. I still learned quite a bit from him.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Anita was a very ineffective TA and showed a clear lack of understanding about what was being taught in class. Did not attend class and was not familiar with Desai's lecture slides. Her review session before the midterm was completely unhelpful and almost laughable how little she knew and how poorly she explained the information. Her explanation of grading for homework was also not helpful. She should not be allowed to act as a TA again.Heather Sipsma, however, was an EXCELLENT TA. Very helpful, very accessible, and very knowledgeable. Her review session before the final was extremely helpful and she was very sensitive to questions and concerns about the final. I really enjoyed the lecture she gave to class; it was very pertinent information. She should definitely TA this course again!
N/A
bad. not helpful, dont seem to know the information well enough to explain it.
Heather was very helpful. I didn't have much interaction with Anita.
i did not have contact with the TAs.
Horrific TAs.

Heather and Anita were both very responsive to questionsin person or by email. At times it appeared that Anita had either not received the hw ahead of time or had not reviewed it b/c when asked about specific problems did not seem familiar with material. Would have been helpful if she had attempted to answer in a more conceptual manner. As students already have the slides, questions may be better answered by looking to other sources or ways to explain the material.
Heather -- excellent.Anita -- fair.

The TAs varied in skill. Anita was weaker. She was harder to reach via email and answered a number of questions in her office hours incorrectly. Heather is a great TA. She can explain the problems well and is very responsive to email questions.
Anita is very helpful and should be commended.
I did not work with any ofthe TAs
TA's overall did well, could be more structured/prepared for review sessions.
Heath Sipsma is awesome - incredibly helpful and patient during office hours. Anita was equally helpful.
There wasn't too much interaction with the TAs--I didn't go to their office hours; I only saw their grading on my HW.

The TA's were Heather and Anita. Anita seemed very unclear on many of the topics. She was not helpful in office hours. Heather was helpful but hard to get a hold of. I felt that their grading was often inconsistent with each other; particularly on the exams (their grading and comments on both seemed rushed and not AT ALL thorough.) All in all, just mediocre ta's. I would not recommend continuing to use them to the professor.
I did not interact with the TAs in this course.

There were two TAs assigned to this course: Anita Sung and Heather Sipsma. The only contact I had with Anita was from a review session she did for the midterm - the review was short and she didn't really explain things very clearly. Heather did teach a class and hold a review session for the final exam and I felt that she explained the concepts very well and answered questions in a clear and understandable way.
Heather was quite helpful; Anita seems quite punitive and generally unhelpful.
Heather gave a great and very helpful lecture
I did not have much interaction with the TA except for one visit to her during office hours. The TA was pretty helpful during this visit.

I was not impressed by my understanding of Anita's reaction to the above-described misunderstanding about homework and effort-sharing. It seems a better course of action would have been to clarify the rules about homework, rather than simply reporting a student to the academic advisory board. My personal experience with all of the TAs associated with this course is without complaint, however.
The TA was a ridiculous grader. She was so picky. We lost points for stupid stuff, not for misunderstanding.
Anita was a really good TA, always available for answers and good explanations.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: An interesting and enjoyable class for people who are required to take it (CDE/SBS), but not necessary for individuals who already learned a lot in Epi I and are not required to take this course.
The course is necessary.
hard, required.
Yes, I would recommend it, but it is very similar to Epi I. I feel the new things we learned were beneficial, but could have easily been taught in Epi I.

I would not recommend this course for anyone who is not in an epidemiology track. Majority of the material was similar to epi I. This class is recommended only for those that want additional info, otherwise, epi I is sufficient for general info.
Not necessary unless you are Epi inclined.
Good continuation of epi principles, although more interaction would be useful. perhaps an additional/ optional 1 credit to discuss the papers?
It's Epi II - take it if you have to, but expect a lot of repetition from Epi I.
This is a great course that summarizes the 2nd level of Epi taught at EPH.
This course is a upgraded version of epi I, but you'd better take both of them then you will have better sense in many epi topics.

I would recommend this course only if you had trouble with Epi I. Otherwise, if you have to take it, don't worry much about the readings or even coming to class until the last two or three lectures. Homework assignemnts and exams are pretty straightforward.
This course is essentially a review Epi I, withsome new material to complement first semester's information.
Chances are you have to take it, but it really is a fun course. Repetitive, again, which might be a little frustrating, but he does find the most unique examples to demonstrate his points.
EXCELLENT course. The professor is FANTASTIC.
I would recommend it to anyone considering applied epidemiological study in their future. It's super relevant and well-taught.

Yes, definitely. I enjoyed this much better than Epi 1. It's a nice course to make sure you have grasped all those hard concepts in Epi 1 and can learn to apply them in your own epi studies and critique journal articles.

This course is a helpful refresher on topics from epi I and also introduces new analysis tools. Given the foundational nature of epidemiology in public health, I recommend this course as a way of solidifying skills and concepts.

I would definitely recommend this course. Dr. Desai is an excellent teacher and while many of the concepts are the same from the first semester, I didn't feel like the course was a waste of time - I came to understand the concepts better and learned a lot from this course.

This class is 100% redundant with Epi I. Do not take it unless you absolutely have to. It's not a bad class (the slides and lectures are clear and instructive), but it is extremely boring and tedious in light of the fact that the lectures are almost identical to those in Epi I.
Excellent.
Great class! A really in-depth way to look at epidemiology.
Similar to epi I but greater depth. Develops critical reading skills.

As an EMD student, I chose to take this course instead of data management. I am really happy with that decision and would recommend that to any other students who don't really need data management for what they want to do.
it was okay, but too much a repeat of epi I.
Required for CDE
Good useful course, although not much developed over Epi I.
